sentences.sentence: Michelle Levy's Quality of Advice Review is an overdue blueprint for fixing Australia's broken financial advice system and winding back the regulatory overreach that the review says is an "undoubted impediment" to ordinary Australians accessing affordable advice.

Having promised to do something within three months of taking office to clean up the "hot mess" of financial advice, Financial Services Minister Stephen Jones should get on with implementing a blueprint backed by the Coalition, finance sector organisations, and most of big super.

Instead, after sitting on the review for two months, Mr Jones has announced a fresh round of public consultations while indicating he will seek a second opinion by "stress-testing" the proposed model with other experts.This will allow the consumer protection lobby to ramp up the scare campaign that has already started amid warnings that exempting financial institutions from the "best interest" test introduced as part of the Rudd government's Future of Financial Advice reforms a decade ago is a recipe for Hayne royal commission-style Mark II financial services misconduct.

But the kind of two-tiered system the Levy review recommends, to allow financial institutions to provide financial advice, is the direction in which regulation is heading in Singapore, Britain, the US and elsewhere.
Sticking with the unsatisfactory status quo will mean that ordinary Australians continue to get no advice at all because they cannot afford a premium service.
Ms Levy says the existing "regulatory framework is complex, difficult to understand and difficult to comply with".

Hence, she recommends that professional financial advisers no longer be required by law to prepare statements of advice that run to hundreds of pages that clients rarely want or read, and which only pushes up the cost, pricing consumers out of receiving "comprehensive" financial advice.But the guts of the review is really targeting the overly prescriptive regulatory inflexibility that prevents people with relatively simple financial affairs from receiving basic or general advice from the financial institutions they entrust their money to.

It is absurd that banks and superannuation funds cannot answer simple questions from customers about things like transitioning to retirement or even opening a new account for fear of triggering complex advice laws.

To reduce the impediments and risk, the review proposes a two-tiered regulatory framework that would exempt financial institutions from the tick-a-box "best interests test", which would be replaced with a simplified "good advice" duty modelled on the principles of retail and consumer law.This would make it easier for super funds and banks to give affordable advice to all who want it.

This is also about making the regulatory framework fit for purpose in the age of ChatGPT, so that a "variety and diversity" of low-fee business models can emerge, such as scalable and automated digital advice.
This will still require proper management of conflicts of interest and adequate product disclosures rules.

But there is no shortage of regulation in this area, with the ban on conflicted investment commissions introduced by FOFA and anti-hawking rules recommended by Hayne to remain under the proposed shake-up.

Amid the heightened scrutiny of the post-Hayne world, giving dodgy or deceptive advice to customers will hardly be in any financial institution's best interests.The Albanese government should seize the opportunity to fill in the missing piece in the retirement incomes framework established by a former Labor government.

Over the past 30 years, the compulsory super system, whose default settings are rooted in our antiquated industrial relations system, has allowed Australians to accumulate a retirement savings pool of about $3.4 trillion that is mostly managed by part union-owned industry funds.
The success of the super system set up by a collectivist labour movement should make fixing financial advice a priority for Labor.

Ironically, the inability of workers to access quality affordable advice about their super nest eggs means that in retirement less-informed individuals are forced to manage complex risks like longevity and how to draw down on their savings.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Michelle Levy's Quality of Advice Review is an overdue blueprint for fixing Australia's broken financial advice system and winding back the regulatory overreach that the review says is an "undoubted impediment" to ordinary Australians accessing affordable advice. Having promised to do something within three months of taking office to clean up the "hot mess" of financial advice, Financial Services Minister Stephen Jones should get on with implementing a blueprint backed by the Coalition, finance sector organisations, and most of big super. Instead, after sitting on the review for two months, Mr Jones has announced a fresh round of public consultations while indicating he will seek a second opinion by "stress-testing" the proposed model with other experts.This will allow the consumer protection lobby to ramp up the scare campaign that has already started amid warnings that exempting financial institutions from the "best interest" test introduced as part of the Rudd government's Future of Financial Advice reforms a decade ago is a recipe for Hayne royal commission-style Mark II financial services misconduct. But the kind of two-tiered system the Levy review recommends, to allow financial institutions to provide financial advice, is the direction in which regulation is heading in Singapore, Britain, the US and elsewhere. Sticking with the unsatisfactory status quo will mean that ordinary Australians continue to get no advice at all because they cannot afford a premium service. Ms Levy says the existing "regulatory framework is complex, difficult to understand and difficult to comply with". Hence, she recommends that professional financial advisers no longer be required by law to prepare statements of advice that run to hundreds of pages that clients rarely want or read, and which only pushes up the cost, pricing consumers out of receiving "comprehensive" financial advice.But the guts of the review is really targeting the overly prescriptive regulatory inflexibility that prevents people with relatively simple financial affairs from receiving basic or general advice from the financial institutions they entrust their money to. It is absurd that banks and superannuation funds cannot answer simple questions from customers about things like transitioning to retirement or even opening a new account for fear of triggering complex advice laws. To reduce the impediments and risk, the review proposes a two-tiered regulatory framework that would exempt financial institutions from the tick-a-box "best interests test", which would be replaced with a simplified "good advice" duty modelled on the principles of retail and consumer law.This would make it easier for super funds and banks to give affordable advice to all who want it. This is also about making the regulatory framework fit for purpose in the age of ChatGPT, so that a "variety and diversity" of low-fee business models can emerge, such as scalable and automated digital advice. This will still require proper management of conflicts of interest and adequate product disclosures rules. But there is no shortage of regulation in this area, with the ban on conflicted investment commissions introduced by FOFA and anti-hawking rules recommended by Hayne to remain under the proposed shake-up. Amid the heightened scrutiny of the post-Hayne world, giving dodgy or deceptive advice to customers will hardly be in any financial institution's best interests.The Albanese government should seize the opportunity to fill in the missing piece in the retirement incomes framework established by a former Labor government. Over the past 30 years, the compulsory super system, whose default settings are rooted in our antiquated industrial relations system, has allowed Australians to accumulate a retirement savings pool of about $3.4 trillion that is mostly managed by part union-owned industry funds. The success of the super system set up by a collectivist labour movement should make fixing financial advice a priority for Labor. Ironically, the inability of workers to access quality affordable advice about their super nest eggs means that in retirement less-informed individuals are forced to manage complex risks like longevity and how to draw down on their savings.
